They saidmore drivers used the bypass instead of driving through Dinas, the village would be safer for pedestrians and cyclists.Bypass plansThe Arcadis report is going to the Vale cabinet on Monday, March . Community councillors in Dinas Powys had previously complained about the long delays in publishing the report.The road will likely cost about pound million. No funding has been secured yet from the Welsh Government. But the next stage, pending a successful public consultation, would be for the consultants to write up a full business case and for the Vale council to bid for the funding.MORE NEWS:One option includes building a roundabout halfway down the bypass, linking it with Murch Road.Arcadis highlighted several problems with the existing transport infrastructure between Barry and Cardf, including overcrowding rush-hour trains and buses lack of safe walking and cycling routes congestion car accidents and air and noise pollution.They added that new housing developments in the area would likely increase the pressure on the roads and public transport.The report to cabinet said: ldquoIf a bypass is delivered, the existing adverse impact of road traffic, specically through Dinas Powys, could be reduced.ldquoThe journey time and capacity improvements from the bypass would assist public transport and walking and cycling movements through and within Dinas Powys by reducing general traffic volumes.The bypass could also help congestion, journey times, air quality, noise pollution, road safety, and better pedestrian crossings within the village.Cycling routes in the area could also soon be improved. The Vale council is planning to work with Cardf and Newport councils in the coming months on a region-wide cycle network. The Vale is also planning to bring electric Nextbikes to Dinas Powys soon, similar to in Penarth. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... Over one in three Cardf and Vale residents have had the vaccine so far and each person who is vaccinated is helping to protect our older and vulnerable family members.ldquoI really would encourage all adult members of our local communities in Cardf and Vale of Glamorgan to take up the vaccine when it is offered. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityKatie Morgan, , from Penarth but now lives in Sully, will be taking up her jewellery business full-time at the end of this month after working as a nanny for the past four years.Her business, Sea Rose Jewellery, offers handmade necklaces, rings, and bracelets using sea glass ndash either that the customer has collected, or Miss Morgan has from St Maryrsquos Well Bay.ldquoI spent my childhood walking along the beaches in Penarth, Sully, and Barry, she said.Katie Morgan in her workshop ldquoI came across St Maryrsquos Well Bay years ago and was enticed by how quiet and peaceful it was. After noticing beautul colours amongst the pebbles, I discovered the bayrsquos sea glass and would spend hours collecting it.ldquoI eventually had jars full and wanted to turn the glass into something special.Miss Morgan began making jewellery after moving out of her family home and wanted to take up a new hobby so began learning how to wire wrap and turning her own collection of sea glass into necklaces.Some of the handmade rings on offerAfter gting a few to friends, they encouraged her to start selling them. As people would now be paying for them, Miss Morgan wanted to make them long-lasting and began using real silver.MORE NEWS:This introduced her to silversmithing, and she has spent the last two years teaching herself how to silversmith.A iety of coloured sea glass is available ldquoEach piece is entirely handmade by me," she added.ldquoTo make a sea glass necklace, for example, I start by creating a custom-made bezel, which holds the sea glass securely. I then solder hoops onto the bezel so that it can be hung from a chain.ldquoNext, I cut the chain to size and hand-make the clasp before soldering onto the chain using jump rings. This makes the chain sturdy and durable. title: oxford island play park refurbishment approved
story: Motorcyclist dies in two vehicle collision in NI town   Community rallies to help young family left homeless after fireNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsPoliticsOxford Island play park refurbishment approvedA proposal to upgrade the play park near the Lough Neagh Discovery Centre at Oxford Island has been approved by Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council’s planning committee.By The NewsroomThursday, th March , : pm  "       "  The application to refurbish the play park m west south west of Lough Neagh Discovery Centre on the Annaloiste Road, Lurgan, was brought before the committee as it is a Council owned site.The application sought approval to refurbish the existing play park with an extension to the site area, removal of existing equipment, bins, seating and furniture and replace them with new bitmac and wetpour surfacing, fencing, play equipment, bins and street furniture.Members of the committee were made aware the existing play park at the proposed site is . hectares in size and the proposed site also includes a portion of grassed area that is approximately . hectares in size."The existing play park is bounded by a low post and wire fence approximatelym in height and there is a public footpath separatingthe park from a forest and trees to the west and a public footpath separatingthe site to the south.The adjacent water feature will remain unchanged.Members were also made aware the proposed play equipment and street furniture is of an improved quality and provides access for people with disabilities.The new proposal includes  pieces of play equipment including bespoke timber play equipment for the site on a new bound rubber safety surface. The proposal also includes  sun seats and three picnic tables."There will be new pathways to access the site and a new .m high chestnutpale perimeter fence.There will be no change to pedestrianor vehicular movementas a result of this development. Members were advised the existing nature reserve, marina and park already attract a signicant number of visitors and there are existing pedestrian and cycle linkages.The planning office responsible for the case confirmed the officer’s recommendation was to approve the application.The Chair of the committee, Councillor Darren McNally noted the wooded area to one side of the play park and asked how it was secured. He was advised there will be a .m high fence around the play area.Councillor Tim McClelland askedofficers were content the parking provision remains adequate at the site.The planning officer advised the Department for Infrastructure had been consulted and accepted that this new attraction may well increase visitor numbers but said despite this, officers are content with the number of spaces available.Alderman Kenneth Twyble said both he and Councillor Declan McAlinden represent this area and described the Lough Neagh Discovery Centre and its surroundings as “the jewel in our crown”.“I think this is wonderful and we must give it our total support,” said Alderman Twyble.“There is a y road down to it but that is part of the facilities. This is a welcome piece of good news for the area.”Councillor Ciaran Toman askeda safety barrier had been considered for users of the park and his question was answered by Alderman Twyble who informed him there was a one-way system in operation and the paths keep people separatefrom vehicles.Councillor Declan McAlinden said the redevelopment of this play park would be an “excellent addition to what is already there”.and proposed the recommendation to approve the planning application.This proposal was seconded by Alderman Twyble and the committee voiced its agreement.Call for action over troubled GP Practice - read hereEditor’s message:Thank you for reading this article. stFermanagh and Omagh District Councilrsquos St Patrickrsquos Festival plans finalisedReporter: Name Last NameWednesday  March  :PREPARATIONS are at an advanced stage for Fermanagh and Omagh District Council’s St Patrick’s Festival  which takes place this year from Friday, March  to . The Festival, launched recently by the chair of the council, councillor Diana Armstrong, while dferent in nature to previous events, will be one of the largest and most ambitious virtual programmes undertaken by Fermanagh and Omagh District Council. Councillor Armstrong said: The programme is a rich and ied celebration of all that is good about St Patrick’s Day and while it is certainly dferent to previous years, it still affords us the opportunity to celebrate in a connected and positive way.” A full programme of virtual entertainment featuring music, dance, storytelling and arts and crafts will be live streamed from the Ardhowen and Strule Arts Centre. There is something for everyone with music from the Tumbling Paddies, Cliona Hagan, The Drunken Lullabies and The Logues to name but a few. Arts and Crafts sessions are also programmed together with storytelling in both English and Irish and a session of Folk Tales from Fermanagh.  ‘The Story of Saint Patrick’, a short film charting Saint Patrick’s le from his abduction at the age of  to hisas an adult bringing Christianity to the local population was launched on the council’s social media channels on Tuesday, March . The popular St Patrick’s Festival Primary Schools art exhibition s again this year, albeit virtually and will be launched on Friday, March . A number of virtual community initiatives, supported by Fermanagh and Omagh District Council, will take place across the district as part of the Festival. For further information on the St Patrick’s Festival programme, visit the council website atwww.fermanaghomagh or the venue Facebook pages.  addthis,     Leave your commentTyrone Constitution- High NameThursday  March  :PRE-school, nursery and primary schools pupils in P to P will remain in school until the start of the Easter break. The decision, which was agreed by the Executive today, means that the youngest pupils will continue with face-to-face teaching for the remainder of this term. Decisions on the timing for theof other primary and post-primary pupils will be considered next Tuesday as part of an overall review of the current restrictions. Students in years  to , who will be awarded qualication results this summer, willto full time face-to face teaching with effect from March , . Education Minister Peter Weir said: “I welcome the decision by the Executive today to allow the youngest pupils to continue with face-to-face teaching until the start of the Easter holidays. “I know that many schools, parents and other pupils want clarity on when more year groups will be ing.
